Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Digitally Addressable and Scalable Laser Fabrication of 3D Gradient Index Nanostructures and Nanophotonics Circuits

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for the integration of advanced numerical tools with laser nano-manufacturing techniques. The numerical tools, called transformation optics, will be used to calculate three-dimensional structures with pre-determined optical functions. The designed structures will be fabricated by multiple laser beam-enabled patterning techniques. The three-dimensional laser patterns will be controlled by a mini liquid crystal display (LCD) with very high numbers of pixels. The numerical information will be displayed to encode the laser beam pixel by pixel. This will enable high-precision and rapid production of nanostructures with pre-designed optical properties. A large number of functional nanostructures will be produced by rapidly changing the numerical coding information displayed on the mini LCD. The above techniques will also be used to fabricate optical circuits by adding light paths and controlling the light inside.

The results of this research will lead to improvements in the design of optical devices and the development of an advanced laser fabrication capability. These new digital design and fabrication tools will enable the rapid design, verification, and fabrication of functional nanostructures and devices for telecommunication, sensing, and imaging applications. The digital display-enabled laser fabrication technique will drastically simplify the laser nano-manufacturing process and improve the process control. The single laser exposure and large-volume patterning process will reduce the manufacturing cost, making the process industrially and technically attractive. This research will also provide educational opportunities to a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This nano-science and engineering research project was carried out collaboratively between the University of Pittsburgh and the University of North Texas. The project developed both scientific knowlege and engineering techniques to design, simulate, synthesize, and fabricate nano-optical materials and nano-optical structures with feature sizes between 15 nm and 500 nm for optical sensing for fiber  optic and on-chip applications.

Using tranformational optic design method, this project design 3D photonic structures to control the flow of light on-chip and on the surface of specialty fibers. Using a polymer-based template fabrication approach, our research team has successfully developed a material engienering scheme to control porosity of functional metal oxide materials and their dopant variants at length of 10-50 nm. Using this approach, refractive indices, absorption properties, and chemical reactivities of metal oxides can be controlled across a wide temperature ranges. With a combined efforts of optical design and nanomaterial synthesis, we have successfully realized unique 3D photonic structures made of porous functional metal oxide materials for optical display, imaging, and sensing applications.

With successful development of nanomaterial fabrication, noble-metal dopant metal oxide nano-materials with appropriate refractive indices were successfully integrated on specialty optical fibers for distributed chemical sensing for energy applications. This new R&D tool was successfully deployed to probe temperature and chemical reaction during operation of solid oxide fuel cells at 700C. The fundamental scientific research enabled by this research grant lead to scientific knowledges in nanoscience and optics and also new sensor tools for energy applications.
